channel.title: Comments on: Choking At the Last Second

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Molokai, you crack me up. Hahaha. Thanks for giving me a good laugh today!
item.content:encoded: Molokai, you crack me up. Hahaha. Thanks for giving me a good laugh today!

item.title: By: MolokaiCowboy
item.dc:creator: MolokaiCowboy
item.description: My 'Conversation' with Lee Sedol... MC: Are you ready to play Bengozen? LS: Never heard of him. New 9p? MC: Perhaps even stronger! LS: Noooo!!! What is his style? MC: They say he is 21st century Go Siegen. He begins with 1. L11. LS: Ha! Even beginner know that is not a good first move. It takes many stones to make territory in the center. MC: But Bengozen has looked further. He says that is true but it takes even more stones to surround it, kill! LS: Ahh...!?! MC: He also plays Reverse Moyo strategy. LS: Reverse Moyo? What is that? MC: Make influence from center. Then sides and corners become his more easily, make territory. In regular Moyo only 50% become territory. In Bengozen Reverse Moyo - 70%! LS: How he discover this Reverse Moyo? MC: He study Takagawa games standing on head, looking in mirror. LS: A genius! This Bengozen is too strong for me. Tell him I am busy with Gu Li jubango!
item.content:encoded:
My ‘Conversation’ with Lee Sedol…
MC: Are you ready to play Bengozen?
LS: Never heard of him. New 9p?
MC: Perhaps even stronger!
LS: Noooo!!! What is his style?
MC: They say he is 21st century Go Siegen. He begins with 1.
L11.
LS: Ha! Even beginner know that is not a good first move. It
takes many stones to make territory in the center.
MC: But Bengozen has looked further. He says that is true
but it takes even more stones to surround it, kill!
LS: Ahh…!?!
MC: He also plays Reverse Moyo strategy.
LS: Reverse Moyo? What is that?
MC: Make influence from center. Then sides and corners
become his more easily, make territory. In regular Moyo only 50% become
territory. In Bengozen Reverse Moyo – 70%!
LS: How he discover this Reverse Moyo?
MC: He study Takagawa games standing on head, looking in
mirror.
LS: A genius! This Bengozen is too strong for me. Tell him I
am busy with Gu Li jubango!

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Fantastic reference to "The Master of Go." I certainly hope that I will be able to "rid myself of the desire to win" soon so that I can get down to the core of my true abilities. Thanks for the reminder and support man!
item.content:encoded: Fantastic reference to “The Master of Go.” I certainly hope that I will be able to “rid myself of the desire to win” soon so that I can get down to the core of my true abilities. Thanks for the reminder and support man!

item.title: By: scott
item.dc:creator: scott
item.description: Being able to learn your weaknesses through introspection is a great strength that is important to any competitive sport. I am happy that you now have a chance to overcome it. This post also reminded me of some professional go players that were discussed in "The Master Of Go" by Yusanari Kawabata. One player sat with his eyes closed while waiting for his opponent to play. The reason he did this was that during this time he was ridding himself of the desire to win. Another young professional nonchalantly opened up and read a magazine while waiting for his opponent to play. Kawabata mentions that this player had later gone insane, and he thinks that because of his precarious state of nerves he could not stand the time of deliberation while waiting for his opponent to play. Just something to think about.
item.content:encoded:
Being able to learn your weaknesses through introspection is a great strength that is important to any competitive sport. I am happy that you now have a chance to overcome it.
This post also reminded me of some professional go players that were discussed in “The Master Of Go” by Yusanari Kawabata.
One player sat with his eyes closed while waiting for his opponent to play. The reason he did this was that during this time he was ridding himself of the desire to win.
Another young professional nonchalantly opened up and read a magazine while waiting for his opponent to play. Kawabata mentions that this player had later gone insane, and he thinks that because of his precarious state of nerves he could not stand the time of deliberation while waiting for his opponent to play.
Just something to think about.
